title: Ovich News
description: A flagship platform of the Ovich Media Group, required a digital infrastructure that could handle rapid content publishing and high concurrent traffic. We engineered a solution that prioritizes performance and reliability, ensuring that breaking news reaches the public without delay.

techStack.purpose: was implemented to create clean, high-performance HTML templates. This allows for rapid server-side rendering, which is critical for news sites where speed directly impacts user retention and SEO rankings.
A robust Node.js/Express environment manages the complex routing of categories, tags, and real-time news feeds.
was developed to ensure a "news-first" layout—clean typography, clear hierarchies, and a mobile-responsive design that works perfectly for readers on the go.
acts as the central repository for thousands of articles, ensuring that even as the archive grows, search and retrieval remain instantaneous.

We integrated AWS S3 for media asset management. All news images and videos are served through this global cloud infrastructure to ensure maximum uptime and fast loading regardless of the user's location.

solutions: Initially, we utilized Multer to handle image and video uploads directly into the Node.js file system on Heroku. However, due to Heroku’s "ephemeral" file system behavior, every time the server restarted or deployed a fresh build, all uploaded news media were wiped out. This created a high risk of data loss for a news organization that relies on a permanent archive.

AWS S3 Cloud Integration: To solve the file deletion issue, we decoupled the media storage from the web server. We migrated the entire upload pipeline to AWS S3. Now, when a reporter uploads a news image, it is sent directly to an encrypted S3 bucket. This ensures that media remains persistent, highly available, and globally accessible, regardless of server restarts or updates.

As a media group, Ovich needed a way to manage various contributors, from junior reporters to senior editors, while also handling a growing base of subscribed readers. Without a structured system, the risk of unauthorized content changes or data breaches was a major concern.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): We engineered a sophisticated RBAC system integrated with a user subscription model. This allows the Ovich Media Group to assign specific permissions to different staff levels.
We built a custom registration and login system that allows readers to sign up and create unique profiles. This ensures that every comment and reply is tied to a verified user, significantly reducing spam and improving the quality of the conversation.

conclusion: Scaling a brand across 7 nations requires more than just a website; it requires a global digital strategy. At WebDev247, we provided the engineering backbone that allowed Ovich News to dominate international headlines.
